title: Lincoln Home National Historic Site: Abraham Lincoln's Journey Home
body: Explore This Park    Learn About the Park     History & Culture     Stories     Abraham Lincoln's Journey Home                Abraham Lincoln's Journey Home              Abraham Lincoln's Journey Home A celebration of the life and legacy of Abraham Lincoln on the 150 Anniversary of his national funeral April 18 – May 3, 2015          NPS Graphic  From April 18 through May 3, 2015, the National Park Service commemorated the 150 anniversary of the funeral of Abraham Lincoln with a program called "Abraham Lincoln's Journey Home." This series of presentations honored his legacy in each of the major cities that held a funeral for Lincoln in 1865, from Washington, DC to Springfield, Illinois. The programs focused on Lincoln's vision for America as he expressed it during his life, a vision that moved the nation from Civil War toward Civil Rights. Each program began with a National Park Service Park Ranger who not only served to open the program, but whose own story stands as an example of Lincoln's vision for America. The program featured accomplished Lincoln actor, Fritz Klein, who gave a presentation on Abraham Lincoln's commitment to the idea that the United States was "conceived in liberty and dedicated to the proposition that all men are created equal." Click here to download this poster graphic (large file).      Click here to view an overview video of the "Abraham Lincoln's Journey Home" program.             Lincoln actor Fritz Klein and Park Ranger Duey Kol approaching the Pennsylvania State Capitol in Harrisburg. NPS Photo  The Schedule for Lincoln's Journey Home Saturday, April 18  Washington, DC New York Avenue Presbyterian Church 5:30p.m.  Sunday, April 19  Washington, DC Frederick Douglass National Historic Site 2:00p.m.  Monday, April 20  Washington, DC African American Civil War Memorial 10:30 a.m.  Tuesday, April 21  Baltimore, Maryland B&O Railroad Museum 1:00 p.m. Select this link to watch the program that took place at the B &O Railroad Museum.   Harrisburg, Pennsylvania Pennsylvania State Capitol 7:00 p.m.  Wednesday, April 22  Philadelphia, Pennsylvania Independence National Historical Park 1:00 p.m.  Thursday, April 23  Philadelphia, Pennsylvania Independence National Historical Park 10:00 a.m.   Trenton, New Jersey New Jersey State House 2:00 p.m.  Friday, April 24  New York, New York Federal Hall National Memorial 11:00 a.m.   Federal Hall National Memorial 1:00 p.m.  Saturday, April 25  Albany, New York New York State Capitol 3:30 p.m.     New York State Capitol 6:30 p.m.  Sunday, April 26  Buffalo, New York Buffalo History Museum 3:00 p.m.  Monday, April 27  Buffalo, New York Theodore Roosevelt Inaugural National Historic Site 9:30 a.m.     Central Library Auditorium 12:00 p.m.  Tuesday, April 28  Cleveland, Ohio Old Stone Church 7:00 p.m.  Wednesday, April 29  Columbus, Ohio Ohio State Capitol 6:00 p.m. Select this link to watch the program that took place at the Ohio State Capitol.  Thursday, April 30    Indianapolis, Indiana Indiana State Capitol 11:00 a.m. Select this link to watch the program that took place at the Indiana State Capitol.     Michigan City, Indiana National Guard Armory 6:00 p.m.  Friday, May 1  Michigan City, Indiana Elston Middle School 10:00 a.m.     National Guard Armory 12:00 p.m.     Chicago, Illinois Chicago History Museum 7:00 p.m.  Saturday, May 2  Chicago, Illinois Harold Washington Library 2:00 p.m. Select this link to watch the program that took place at the Harold Washington Library.      Sunday, May 3  Springfield, Illinois Old State Capitol State Historic Site 10:00 a.m. Select this link to watch the program that took place at the Old State Capitol State Historic Site.           Students at Elston Middle School in Michigan City, Indiana with their copies of the "Abraham Lincoln's Journey Home" handbook.
